The price of addon of the week goes to: <https://github.com/trentmwillis/ember-exam>

attachments.title: trentmwillis/ember-exam
attachments.text: ember-exam - Run your tests with better filtering, randomization, splitting, and parallelization for beautiful tests.

text: looks extremely promising
I have a project with ~15m test suite
let’s see how it works
it should be pretty linear
I’ve been using it for a while now, it works great :slightly_smiling_face:
we’re using it on circleci and parallelizing it on 3 cores brought down the time by 50%
it’s a shame that npm alone is nearly 1/3 of the build time
also the splitting (even the weighted version) doesn’t really make perfect slices of your tests
it would be nice to save the times each test took to run and then use that cache to split the tests
well, I don’t think that my tests diverge in length enough to care about that
if I go from ~15m to ~5m by spawning 3/4 parallel builds
I’m ok with that

text: ^ that’s a surprise
DockYard has proved itself to be a stepping-stone company for a lot of ember folks
Wow
That sounds pretty awesome
<@U03V8V08M>: I thought most of the big ember peeps there were contractors
like robert jackson
Robert Jackson is at Twitch
<@U047GTU64>: no, surprisingly not
I spoke to Brian Cardarella about this a while back
there’s far less of a contractor culture in the US
<@U043AB2QT>: before that was dockyard iirc
correct
Yup

>  less of a contractor culture in the US

salaries are higher for perm staff
also things like health insurance
my personal opinion here is that the tech employers need to acknowledge that they _have_ to make a perm job attractive if they want someone to stay
hmm yeah I agree
they do get more off being perm that being temporary
feel like it contrasts with the UK - given the fiscal side of things, etc
the main/only reason to be a contractor is mostly tax-related
Agreed, that is a big one for me
huge IMO
I don’t think that for a company paying a contractor vs hiring a perm
is very different
money-wise
but it is for the one that gets paid
<@U040MK408>: I’d say if its a mid-to big sized company with perks, etc
the differences are fairly small
yeah
<@U03V8V08M>: how much would you say is the proportion here perm employees to contractors?
same question, but in the context of the US market
here in London or here in the UK?
UK
actually both
:alien:
I don’t know for sure, but I’d say majority perm
I think here in this particular part of town we have a skewed sense of things
I couldn’t give a percentage
because there are lots of startups around who can’t justify permanent staff at the outset
but in london I don’t think the % of contractors is > 20%
<@U03V8V08M>: yeah but I’d say big employers also look for temporary work
that sounds about right to me
as the future of everything is becoming project-based
so more on-demand team assembly
ship a project and then hand it over
and work from Platja D'Aro
in the middle of nowhere
the training I delivered for a large company wasn’t learning ember because they were oging to use it
the company paid an agency to build a project and their tech team was being handed over that software
<@U040MK408>: remember yuri?
he’s based in Siberia!
I know
lol
I still suffer him
how cray is that
xD
HAHA
from time to time
#shotsfired
in my experience, most software companies are looking to build permanent teams
:boom:
yep thats the priority for a product-centric company
but you still have agencies
and not-so complex products
haha, well
having worked for an agency that went out of business this year
I don't think the future is looking so rosy for agencies
but, my point-of-view is also skewed there
there’s another aspect to all this
which is career trajectory
something I must admit I’d now thought about until relatively recently
and another area where we differ from the US, I think
wait not sure if I got that
are agencies not a thing in the US?
or at least not as much of a thing
I’m still talking UK-only
cos I don’t know a thing about the US market
agencies certainly are a thing in the US
DockYard are a notable one
I mixed my points together a little
I’m saying the "career trajectory" angle is something people prioritise differently between here and the US
how so?
I doubt knowledge workers in the UK (especially London) will start to lean towards the majority being fulltime. Particularly with this in the pipeline: <http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-36699642>

attachments.title: Brexit: George Osborne pledges to cut corporation tax - BBC News
attachments.text: Chancellor George Osborne plans to cut corporation tax to less than 15% to encourage businesses to still invest in the UK following the referendum vote.
attachments.fallback: BBC News: Brexit: George Osborne pledges to cut corporation tax - BBC News

text: this is only anecdotal, but amongst peer groups in London and the US, the US crowd seem more interested in the idea of working towards roles with more responsibility (and larger salaries)
climbing the career ladder

```
Chancellor George Osborne plans to cut corporation tax to less than 15% to encourage businesses to still invest in the UK following the referendum vote.
```

:joy:
or plainly translated to
“pls do not leave us"
If the corp tax goes close to Ireland and London retains passporting right to the EU its a no brainer.
<@U03V8V08M>: I think thats because the margins are better for perm employees though
more benefits, more stable - yet quite highly remunerated - salaries
<@U047GTU64>: what do you predict for demand for contractors over the next 5 years?
increase? decrease? stay the same?

But, anyway. Yeah, my experience of FT vs contracting is the the UK does *not* pay well enough on the high end to encourage career progression.

or is that a London thing?

its a London thing

theres definetly more opportunities in london
but thats economies of scale

not mindsets per se

for everyone
(aka, if it’s too niche than conservative buyers are already heading for the exit)
in consulting the really attractive clients are the big ones; the big ones are typically conservative

I’m paraphrasing something Brian has said in blog posts/podcasts

was following up on <@U04BD6KB1>’s point here:
> I definitely get the sense that Brian sees Elixir as a bigger revenue source with clients
oh right
yeah misread your comment
yeah and i think micro-services do allow companies more opportunities to experiment with new server technologies
there was the changelog a while ago which basically said as much
“Rails is too easy to get good at” or something
so the performance story of Elixir, packaged up in container tech might be a nice way to get people to accept it
i commented that in the Elixir meetup
that unlike what most people or non techinical CEOs might think
build in top of a still-quite-niche technology like Elixir
can ease recruiting A LOT
even if the pool of people that know the tech is rather small
because the pool of companies using the tech is even smaller
it’s a built-in filter, effectively
you know that any candidate with experience of the technology is dedicated enough to have made headway in the early days
also elixir is the future, please do join, we have cookies
I’ve observed that the same is true with Ember
it’s a niche technology, so when somebody says they have Ember experience, chances are they’ve a built a reasonably complex project with it
rather than a short-lived or hobby project
with massively popular tools like React or Angular, it’s a way bigger tent and so you don’t get that built-in self-selection
like much much bigger
How much experience would a candidate need if they were willing to join a new firm because of an interest in their tech choices.
i’ll say it: angular is today’s php
php 5.3

also, I think that experience in paradigms is far more important than experience in a specific tech

it’s been a long discussion, so I’m not sure if it has been mentioned, but I’d like to remind people that in the US you have to pay for your own healthcare, which can get really expensive. Hence it’s natural that they get paid more over there
<@U05485UQL>: yeah Healthcare was mentioned at some point
don't (good) American jobs typically have health insurance coverage as a perk?
<@U06BGNMBL>: most
however that leaves you in a bad position if you lose the perk in anyway, or if it doesn’t cover enough
for example, going freelance

and also a lot of money for very limited cover

gosh, yeah
my heart really went out to him, reading that post
before that, he was complaining about the way Obamacare works for freelancers. Real pain in the lower back, and drain in your pockets
